vignette: Leroy is a 34 year old male, whose chief complaint is, “I am having intrusive thoughts.” Leroy reports that “since childhood, I have been experiencing intrusive thoughts.” He reports he has met with a number of psychiatrists in the past, and has tried a range of different psychiatric medications. Leroy reports he was recently recommended by his present physician to see a psychiatrist again, given how distressing his intrusive thoughts have become. His previous psychiatrist started him on Zoloft, and gave him recommendation for community based mental health psychotherapist.  Leroy has been taking the Zoloft (200 mg daily) for about 5 years, for what he states his provider thought was “anxiety or depression.” Leroy acknowledges history of periods of “sadness”, stating “yeah sad, sometimes, but not depressed; when things get out of control; its been a while though; when something feels out of reach.” Denied present or past suicidal ideation, and denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Leroy insists no problems with perceptual distortion or paranoia, and denied thought insertion or thought broadcasting.  Leroy stated that the intrusive thoughts, “first started happening when I was a kid, I was able to cope with them; getting better understanding what they were; ways to get them to go away; calm myself down and regain control and go on with my life; now that is not working.” Leroy states the most recent intrusive thought has been a fear that the chart bus he drives from his local airport to downtown stop will “slide off the road because of ice or snow.” He thinks about this, on average, about 30 to 45 minutes a day.  Leroy endorsed episodes of “panic” and “my body almost feels like its paralyzed; I experience pain from my spine up”, which lasts for a couple of days at a time. With regards to “generalized anxiety”, patient reports “I would have these thoughts about my ailing mother; she has schizophrenia; my body would react to whatever I was thinking about her; my body tenses up when that happens.” Leroy denied any preoccupations about his physical health, nor inability to leave the home because of anxiety. He reports to work regularly, and rarely misses any work unless he is very sick. He says he is never late to work or planned appointments. Leroy has a girlfriend, and says that relationship is going “great.” In his spare time, he continues to join his friends for basketball pickup games and video game nights, which he still enjoys. Leroy does remember a feeling of having to tap the door handle a few times before he opens it, but said this never lasted more than a few second and was not associated with any fear of catastrophic consequences if he did not complete the task.  Leroy acknowledges observed violence/abuse of his parents when growing up, and with harsh parenting to his 3 siblings, patient denied problems with flashbacks, nightmares or hypervigilance associated with the trauma. Patient works second shift, gets home around 1:30 a.m., reports falling asleep at 2:30 a.m. and wakes up at 10/11 a.m., and can typically sleep through the night without interruption. He reports his energy level is “normal through the week.” Denied recent or past mania. Reports contributing stressors are “work --- not the most peaceful environment.” Also reports mother suffers from “type of schizophrenia and for a while she was taking medication and just recently now decided to stop; that’s been going on for quite some time.” Leroy’s urine toxicology returned with marijuana, and TSH level was within normal limits.
diagnosis: Obsessive compulsive disorder (F42.8)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical vignette about Leroy. He's a 34-year-old male with a chief complaint of intrusive thoughts since childhood. The key points here are the long history, the specific intrusive thought about the charter bus sliding off the road, and the fact that he's been on Zoloft for five years for what was thought to be anxiety or depression. He mentions periods of sadness but denies current depression or suicidal ideation.

First, I need to extract and organize the relevant data. Leroy has intrusive thoughts that are time-consuming (30-45 minutes daily) and cause distress. He also mentions episodes of "panic" and bodily sensations like pain from his spine up, lasting a couple of days. There's a history of trauma with observed violence/abuse but no PTSD symptoms like flashbacks or nightmares. He has some compulsive behavior like tapping the door handle briefly but no associated fear. He works regularly, has a good relationship, and enjoys social activities. His mother has schizophrenia, and his urine tox is positive for marijuana.

Now, thinking about differential diagnoses. The primary issue seems to be obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) given the intrusive thoughts that are time-consuming and cause significant distress, even though compulsions aren't prominently mentioned except for the brief door-tapping. However, the thoughts are ego-dystonic and he tries to suppress them, which aligns with OCD. The Zoloft might be partially helping but not fully.

Next, considering the panic episodes. He describes episodes of panic with physical symptoms lasting days, which might indicate panic disorder or possibly another anxiety disorder. But he doesn't mention specific panic attacks with acute onset, so maybe it's more generalized anxiety. However, he denies preoccupation with health or agoraphobia.

The trauma history without PTSD symptoms rules out PTSD. The absence of manic episodes rules out bipolar. The marijuana use could be a substance use issue, but it's not clear if it's causing the symptoms. His sleep schedule is irregular due to work but not necessarily indicative of a sleep disorder.

Other possibilities include adjustment disorder given work stressors, but the symptoms are long-standing. Given the chronic nature since childhood, OCD seems the most fitting. The secondary diagnoses could include other anxiety disorders, trauma-related disorders, and substance use.
model_diagnosis:
1. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder - ICD-10 F42
2. Other Specified Anxiety Disorder (with panic symptoms) - ICD-10 F41.8
3. Cannabis Use Disorder - ICD-10 F12.20
4. Adjustment Disorder - ICD-10 F43.20
5. Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - ICD-10 F43.8

vignette: Emil is a 22 year old male that reports “my mom wanted us to meet because she spent her whole first therapy session talking to another therapist at her new program about how she feels I need help; I suspect it has to do with my multiple sclerosis (MS), recently losing my fiancé (Lizzy), and after loosing my dog that came with my fiancé. I also lost my career as a farmer.” The patient reports “My girlfriend and I had a good relationship when I used to be able to fish with her; she was a blue blood from the Cape.” Patient reports that he survived being “attacked when I was at a local bar about 4 years ago; the guy smashed a few beer bottles on my head; I had to go to the hospital and they did brain scans; I don’t remember what they said they found.” Patient reports that after that attack, he stopped fishing and started drinking alcohol heavily, at least 8 standard drinks per day, resulting in him missing work, the end of his relationship with his girlfriend, and resulted in getting two DUIs. Patient remembers, “I tried cutting down, but I was never able to do it.” The patient has been sober from alcohol for 76 days now. He denied any other drug use. Patient reports that around two years ago, “I was starting having another MS flare, I stopped being able to sleep for about two weeks and felt angry all the time.” Patient reports during that time he took several last minute trips to Baltimore by train, trying to start a new business and during that time had many sexual indiscretions. He states “people said I was acting strange and that I claimed I was a celebrity that was going to find a cure for autism.” Emil states “I felt like I had endless energy and could take on the world.” The patient reports no similar episodes like that since then, and denied any major mood symptoms since that time. Emil denied recent or past hallucinations, paranoia or thought insertion. Emil reports he never experienced trauma, with the exception of losing his girlfriend and dog. The patient denied any recent problems with depressed, sad, or hopeless mood, and denied problems recent problems with decreased need for sleep and associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or feelings of euphoria. He denied recent or past anxiety or panic, nor OCD.
diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, most recent episode manic, in remission (F31.74), Alcohol use disorder, initial remission (F10.21), Mood disorder due to a known physiologic condition with manic features (F06.33)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical case vignette about Emil. I need to extract all relevant information and organize it logically to support my diagnostic reasoning.

First, Emil is a 22-year-old male. He mentions his mom insisted on meeting because she's concerned. Key issues he reports include multiple sclerosis (MS), losing his fiancé Lizzy, losing his dog, and losing his career as a farmer. He had a previous girlfriend who was from a wealthy background ("blue blood from the Cape"), and they used to fish together. 

There's a significant event four years ago where he was attacked at a bar, had beer bottles smashed on his head, and was hospitalized. Brain scans were done, but he doesn't recall the results. After the attack, he stopped fishing and started heavy drinking—at least 8 drinks daily. This led to missing work, ending his relationship, and two DUIs. He tried cutting down but couldn't until recently; he's been sober for 76 days.

Two years ago, during an MS flare, he experienced two weeks of insomnia and constant anger. During that time, he took impulsive trips to Baltimore, attempted starting a business, had many sexual indiscretions, and exhibited grandiose behavior (claiming to be a celebrity who would cure autism). He felt endless energy and like he could take on the world. No similar episodes since, and he denies recent mood symptoms, hallucinations, paranoia, or trauma aside from the losses mentioned. He also denies recent anxiety, panic, or OCD symptoms.

Now, organizing this data: The attack four years ago might have caused a traumatic brain injury (TBI), given the head injury and hospitalization. The heavy drinking starting after that suggests possible alcohol use disorder, especially since it led to DUIs and functional impairment. His recent sobriety is a positive factor.

The episode two years ago is critical: during an MS flare, he had insomnia, anger, impulsivity, grandiosity, increased energy, and goal-directed activity. This sounds like a manic episode, especially since it lasted two weeks. He denies recent symptoms, but that past episode is significant. MS can sometimes trigger mood disorders due to neurological changes.

He also mentions multiple sclerosis, which is a medical condition that can affect mental health. The losses (fiancé, dog, career) are psychosocial stressors that could contribute to mood issues, but he denies current depression.

Differential diagnosis: 
1. Bipolar I Disorder, single manic episode, in partial remission (since he's been sober and without recent symptoms). The past manic episode meets criteria if it caused significant impairment (business ventures, sexual indiscretions). ICD-10: F31.0 for manic episode, but since it's past, perhaps F31.9 for unspecified bipolar. Wait, DSM-5-TR would specify if it's a single manic episode, which is coded as F30.8 for other manic episode or F30.9 unspecified. Actually, bipolar I requires at least one manic episode, so F31.9 might be appropriate.

2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission: He had heavy drinking, inability to cut down, DUIs, and social/occupational problems. Now sober 76 days, so in early remission. ICD-10: F10.21 for alcohol dependence, in early remission.

3. Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury: The head injury four years ago with possible brain scans showing findings. He doesn't recall results, but the attack could have caused residual cognitive issues. Alcohol use could exacerbate this. ICD-10: F06.8 for other specified mental disorders due to known physiological condition, or F07.0 for personality change due to TBI. But given the behavioral changes post-injury, it's plausible.

4. Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct: He experienced multiple losses (fiancé, dog, career) which are stressors. However, he denies recent depressed mood, so maybe not current. But the initial reaction to losses might have triggered the drinking and behavioral issues. ICD-10: F43.25 for adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood, or F43.24 with disturbance of conduct. Given his behaviors, disturbance of conduct might fit.

5. Multiple sclerosis affecting mood: MS is a known cause of mood disorders due to demyelination. The manic episode occurred during an MS flare, suggesting a possible direct physiological effect. ICD-10: F06.34 for bipolar disorder due to MS, or F06.8 for other specified. Since the manic episode might be secondary to MS, that should be considered.

Prioritizing: The manic episode is prominent, so bipolar I is primary. Alcohol use disorder is clear from history. TBI is likely given the head injury. Adjustment disorder might explain some reactions to stressors, but given the manic episode, bipolar takes precedence. MS as an etiological factor for the mood disorder.

So, structured list:
1. Bipolar I Disorder, single manic episode, in partial remission - F31.0 (manic episode without psychotic features) or F31.9 if unspecified. Actually, DSM-5-TR codes: F31.0 for manic episode, but since it's past and he's in remission, maybe F31.79 for other specified bipolar with current episode in partial remission. Let me check: Bipolar I, most recent episode manic, in partial remission is F31.71. Yes, that fits.

2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21

3. Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury, mild - F06.8 (if attributed to TBI) or F07.0 for personality change. Since cognitive issues aren't explicitly stated, but behavioral changes are, maybe F07.0. However, the vignette doesn't detail cognitive deficits, so perhaps other specified mental disorder due to known physiological condition (TBI). Code F06.8.

4. Adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct - F43.24, given the impulsive behaviors following losses.

5. Bipolar and related disorder due to multiple sclerosis, with manic features - F06.34. This is important because the manic episode occurred during an MS flare, suggesting a direct link.

But note: DSM-5-TR allows for both primary and secondary diagnoses. Since the manic episode might be due to MS, it could be coded as F06.34 instead of F31.71. However, the patient has a history of heavy drinking which could also induce manic symptoms. But the timing with MS flare is key. Given the information, I'll list both possibilities, but primary should be the most impactful.

Final list based on likelihood:
Primary: Bipolar I Disorder, most recent episode manic, in partial remission - F31.71
Secondary: Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21
Secondary: Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury, mild - F06.8
Secondary: Adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct - F43.24
Secondary: Bipolar and related disorder due to multiple sclerosis, with manic features - F06.34

Wait, but bipolar due to MS and primary bipolar might be mutually exclusive. In DSM-5-TR, if the mood disorder is due to another medical condition, it's coded separately. The vignette says the manic episode occurred during an MS flare, so it's plausible that MS caused it. However, he also had prior alcohol use which could complicate. Given the data, I think F06.34 should be included as a secondary diagnosis because MS is a known factor.

But in the differential, I need to choose the top 5. Perhaps instead of having two bipolar diagnoses, I should list one as primary and consider the other as secondary if applicable. However, DSM-5-TR would typically code either as primary bipolar or due to medical condition, not both. So I need to decide which is more likely.

Considering the history: The attack four years ago with head injury, then heavy drinking, then two years ago during MS flare a manic episode. The manic episode might be secondary to MS, but also could be primary bipolar triggered by stress or TBI. Given the complexity, I'll list the primary as bipolar due to MS because of the temporal association with the flare.

So revised:
1. Bipolar and related disorder due to multiple sclerosis, with manic features - F06.34
2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21
3. Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury, mild - F06.8
4. Adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct - F43.24
5. Unspecified bipolar and related disorder - F31.9 (if the primary is due to MS, this might be redundant, so maybe another diagnosis)

Wait, I need five distinct diagnoses. Perhaps include PTSD? He was attacked, but he denies trauma except for losses. He doesn't report flashbacks or avoidance, so probably not. What about other conditions? He had impulsive behaviors, so maybe borderline personality traits? But not enough data. 

Another possibility: Substance/medication-induced bipolar disorder due to alcohol? But he was sober during the manic episode, as it was two years ago and he was drinking before but not necessarily during? The vignette says he started drinking after the attack four years ago, and the manic episode was two years ago, so he might have been drinking then. But the episode occurred during an MS flare, so more likely due to MS.

So, my final list:
1. Bipolar and related disorder due to multiple sclerosis, with manic features - F06.34
2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21
3. Mild Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury - F06.8
4. Adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct - F43.24
5. Unspecified depressive disorder - F32.9 (considering his losses, but he denies current depression, so maybe not). Alternatively, other specified trauma-related disorder? But he denies trauma symptoms. 

Perhaps other specified bipolar and related disorder, but that's covered. I think four are sufficient, but the instruction says top five. Maybe include other specified mental disorder due to known physiological condition (MS) for mood symptoms, but that's already in F06.34.

Let me check ICD-10 codes: 
- F06.34 is for bipolar disorder due to known physiological condition (MS).
- F10.21 for alcohol dependence in early remission.
- F06.8 for other specified mental disorders due to brain disease, damage, dysfunction.
- F43.24 for adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct.
- For the fifth, perhaps F07.0 for personality change due to TBI, but that's similar to F06.8. Or F09 for unspecified mental disorder due to known physiological condition.

Given the data, I'll include personality change due to TBI as a possibility because of the behavioral changes post-injury.

So:
1. Bipolar and related disorder due to multiple sclerosis, with manic features - F06.34
2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission - F10.21
3. Personality change due to traumatic brain injury - F07.0
4. Adjustment disorder with disturbance of conduct - F43.24
5. Mild Neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury - F06.8

But having two TBI-related diagnoses might be redundant. Perhaps choose one. Since the vignette doesn't specify cognitive deficits, personality change might be more fitting given the behavioral shift after the attack.

Final decision: 
Primary: Bipolar disorder due to MS because the manic episode is temporally related to MS flare.
Secondary: Alcohol use disorder is clear.
Secondary: TBI-related personality change as he stopped fishing and started drinking impulsively post-injury.
Secondary: Adjustment disorder for reactions to losses.
Secondary: Other specified mental disorder due to TBI for any residual cognitive or mood issues.

I think that's reasonable. Now, outputting only the list without reasoning.

vignette: Neveah is a 14 year old girl that comes to her pediatrician with her mother (presently 4 months pregnant) due to “out of control behaviors at home.” The patient appears restless in the exam room and requiring redirection from her mother throughout the visit. The patient frequently punches her mother in the legs, and in the stomach, and the patient even threw her ipad at the pediatrician when she asked the patient what was upsetting her. Most of the patients psychiatric history is gathered from her mother, given how irritable the patient is during the exam. The mother reports Neveah was born 8 weeks pre-mature, spent about 1 month in the neonatal intensive care unit due to problems with breathing, and ultimately discharged home to her care at one month of age. The patient met developmental milestones on or near expected time, and was “clingy” when she was a toddler, but had no problems making friends in daycare and grade school. When patient was about 11 years of age, her biological father left the home to join the military, and has deployed ever since. Around 12 years of age, around summertime, the patient appeared much more talkative, energetic, and would go several days only needing about 3 hours of sleep at night. She was more impulsive during these times, and believed she had super powers to “make her friends get in trouble at school”, even when she was not at school herself. She was never tired the following day. During that same period, she had many temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day of the week, that seemed disproportionate to circumstances, like having to have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich instead of a peanut butter and fluff sandwich. The tantrums would last several hours in a day. This pattern of behavior would last for several weeks at a time, with periods of months returning to normal mood and behavior. The patient never appeared to be hallucination or responding to internal stimuli, and never appeared sad or depressed. Neveah had to be hospitalized during an episode like this when she was 13 years old. Neveah refuses to take medications for her symptoms. The start of this year academic year, that patient appeared more calm and in good behavioral control, but began to have similar symptoms of irritability, violence at home, not needing to sleep, talking fast, and property destruction at home.
diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, current episode manic (F31.2)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient is a 14-year-old girl presenting with severe behavioral dysregulation, including physical aggression, irritability, and property destruction. Key features include a history of episodic symptoms starting around age 12, with periods of heightened energy, decreased need for sleep (only 3 hours per night), talkativeness, impulsivity, and grandiose beliefs about having superpowers. These episodes last several weeks with intervening periods of normal mood and behavior. There's no reported history of hallucinations, delusions, or depressive symptoms.

The developmental history includes premature birth and NICU stay, but normal milestone achievement. Psychosocial stressors include father's departure at age 11. Current presentation shows severe irritability and aggression toward her pregnant mother.

Considering DSM-5-TR criteria, the episodic nature with clear manic-like symptoms (decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, increased energy) points toward a bipolar spectrum disorder. The absence of depressive episodes and the presence of irritability rather than euphoria suggests a manic or hypomanic episode. The severity requiring hospitalization at age 13 supports this.

Differential diagnosis must consider disorders with similar presentations: disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (but episodic nature rules this out), oppositional defiant disorder (but episodic with manic features), ADHD (but symptoms are episodic, not chronic), and intermittent explosive disorder (but episodes include manic features). The aggression toward mother's pregnancy adds contextual stress but doesn't change core symptoms.

Based on symptom duration and severity, bipolar I disorder seems most fitting given the hospitalization history. The other diagnoses represent common differentials for childhood behavioral dysregulation with irritability.
model_diagnosis:
1. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic, Severe - ICD-10 F31.13
2. Other Specified Bipolar and Related Disorder - ICD-10 F31.89
3. Oppositional Defiant Disorder - ICD-10 F91.3
4. Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Presentation - ICD-10 F90.2
5. Intermittent Explosive Disorder - ICD-10 F63.81

vignette: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.
diagnosis: Acute stress disorder (F43.0)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with symptoms following a traumatic event, including re-experiencing, avoidance, hyperarousal, and dissociative symptoms. 

The key details to consider are the timeline (27 days since trauma), the specific traumatic event (witnessing a death), and the symptom cluster. The patient's description of "hovering above herself" is particularly noteworthy as a dissociative symptom rather than a true hallucination.

For differential diagnosis, acute stress disorder seems most fitting given the duration and symptom profile. PTSD would be considered if symptoms persisted beyond a month. The dissociative episode raises the possibility of a dissociative disorder, but it's likely trauma-related. Adjustment disorder with anxiety is possible but doesn't capture the full symptom complexity. While brief psychotic disorder could be considered for the "hallucination," the context makes trauma-related dissociation more likely.

The ICD-10 codes should accurately reflect these diagnostic considerations while maintaining the one-month timeframe specified in the vignette.
model_diagnosis:
1. Acute Stress Disorder - ICD-10 F43.0
2. Posttraumatic Stress Disorder - ICD-10 F43.10
3. Other Specified Dissociative Disorder (with depersonalization/derealization) - ICD-10 F44.89
4. Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety - ICD-10 F43.22
5. Brief Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F23

vignette: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.
diagnosis: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81) or F33.3 (Depression with psychotic features)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex psychiatric case requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with acute-onset paranoid delusions, auditory hallucinations, and significant functional impairment. Let me systematically break down the key clinical features.

The core symptoms clearly point to a psychotic disorder: fixed false beliefs about parents poisoning/killing him, auditory hallucinations of whispering voices, referential delusions about video game characters, and paranoia affecting behavior. The timeline is crucial - symptoms began 2.5 months ago after a psychosocial stressor (job loss), with progressive worsening.

Given the duration (more than 1 month but less than 6 months) and absence of mood symptoms, Brief Psychotic Disorder fits best as primary diagnosis. Need to consider Schizophreniform Disorder too, but the shorter duration and acute onset favor Brief Psychotic Disorder. Substance-induced and medical causes are ruled out by negative tox screen and denial of head injury.

For differential, Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features warrants consideration due to low energy/motivation symptoms, though psychotic symptoms appear primary. Schizotypal Personality Disorder could explain longstanding odd beliefs but acute onset argues against it. Delusional Disorder might be possible but hallucinations aren't typical. PTSD seems less likely without clear trauma history.
model_diagnosis:
1. Brief Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F23
2. Schizophreniform Disorder - ICD-10 F20.81
3. Major Depressive Disorder, Severe With Psychotic Features - ICD-10 F32.3
4. Delusional Disorder - ICD-10 F22
5. Schizotypal Personality Disorder - ICD-10 F21

vignette: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.
diagnosis: Polysubstance use disorder, severe (F19.20); Alcohol use, with unspecified alcohol induced disorder (i.e. Beer Pantomania) (F10.99)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical vignette about Stacy. She's a 54-year-old Navy Veteran presenting to the ER with sensations of bugs crawling on her, severe thirst, and tremors starting 36 hours after a tummy tuck surgery. She's been on bed rest, which might be relevant.

She mentions drinking 4-5 beers daily and has been using Klonopin for 15 years, bought online since her PCP stopped prescribing it a year ago. Sometimes she combines beer and Klonopin in the morning to manage shakes. That sounds like dependence and possible withdrawal issues.

The chart shows previous ER visits with positive tox for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates, and amphetamines, but she wasn't prescribed the latter two. She admits to trying to cut back on alcohol but drinks more now for the same effect. Labs show severely low sodium and potassium. Denies mood issues or hallucinations.

Hmm, the bugs crawling sensation could be formication, often seen in substance withdrawal or intoxication. Severe thirst and electrolyte imbalances might point to medical issues exacerbated by alcohol use. The timeline after surgery and bed rest could indicate reduced intake or changes in habits triggering withdrawal.

She has a history of polysubstance use based on tox screens, though she only admits to alcohol and benzodiazepines. The combination of substances and withdrawal symptoms suggests Substance-Induced Disorders. Low electrolytes could be due to poor nutrition or alcohol effects.

Primary diagnosis might be Alcohol Withdrawal, given the tremors, attempts to manage shakes with alcohol/benzodiazepines, and increased drinking. Formication can occur in withdrawal. Secondary diagnoses could include Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Withdrawal from benzodiazepines, especially since she's using them without prescription and mixing with alcohol.

vignette: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. Collin’s wife states, “he gets angry of the smallest things.” She goes on to say, “I have to help him get to the bathroom because he is incontinent in the bed very night now”, stating she also has to bath the patient because he can’t find his way around the bathroom. Finally, Collin’s wife states “he goes around making things up when we get around family, sometimes just inventing stuff on the whim, like saying he is making additions to the house or buying a new car, when that is both not true and has nothing to do with the conversation.
diagnosis: Alcohol induced Korsakov’s Syndrome (F10.26); Persistent depressive disorder (F34.1)

The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.

Then there are the movement abnormalities: eye blinking at age 8, neck contortions, and current self-slapping requiring protective gloves. These appear to be complex motor tics. The racial slurs shouted in public settings seem to be complex vocal tics given their involuntary nature and stress association.

For diagnostic reasoning: The combination of social communication deficits and restricted/repetitive behaviors clearly points to autism spectrum disorder as primary. The tic disorder is also prominent but appears secondary given the developmental history. Since both motor and vocal tics have been present for over a year, Tourette's disorder fits best rather than provisional or chronic motor-only tic disorder.

The racial slurs specifically qualify as coprolalia, which supports Tourette's. The self-slapping could be either severe tics or self-injurious behavior sometimes seen in autism, but in context of other tics, it's likely complex motor tics.

Other considerations include possible OCD given repetitive behaviors, but the mother denied rituals. Anxiety disorders could explain some behaviors but wouldn't account for the full picture. The format requires listing one primary and four secondary diagnoses with F-codes. ASD should be primary given its early onset and pervasive impact. vignette: Patient is a 25-year-old transgender male currently living with parents who are reportedly non-supportive, and he works as a hospital lab technician. He presents with severe symptoms characterized primarily by intrusive thoughts related to morality, contamination, and harm. Unwanted thoughts include fears of transmitting sexual fluids to others (which he believes would make him "a rapist"), concerns about accidentally killing insects, moral distress about consuming animal products, and beliefs that viewing violent media constitutes "condoning" violence. To manage these thoughts, he engages in extensive reassurance seeking, repeatedly checking lab results at work, avoiding video games and television, dietary restrictions, and some handwashing. He reports these symptoms significantly interfere with daily functioning, preventing him from living independently. They cause intense distress that frequently culminates in panic attacks. Patient has a complex history related to his gender identity, reporting he has identified as male throughout his life despite being assigned female at birth. He is currently taking low-dose testosterone but conceals this from his family, who he believes are interfering with his plans for gender-affirming surgeries. He reported childhood "delusions" about being "from a fantasy world and chosen by gods" that resolved by age 18. Patient previously took fluvoxamine for panic symptoms until approximately age 24, reporting significant symptom exacerbation upon discontinuation. He describes himself as introverted with limited social connections, identifying as asexual, though questioning if this might be avoidance related to triggering thoughts. His social anxiety dates back to middle and high school, when he was "pretty much mute" with few friends. Patient describes his mood as "always a little depressed" with recent intensification. He endorses feeling sad, empty, and hopeless most days, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, worthlessness, guilt, concentration difficulties, and suicidal ideation. He frequently believes he "needs to be dead" and that suicide would be "the moral thing to do" following morally repugnant intrusive thoughts, though he denies current plan or intent (estimating a 5% chance of suicide within three months). He struggles with activities of daily living without parental support and expresses frustration that his thoughts and behaviors interfere with his gender expression. Despite these significant symptoms, he demonstrates good insight, noting that his thoughts are not consistent with who he is and what he values.
diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder with good insight (F42.2); Gender Dysphoria in Adults, posttransition (F64.0); Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Moderate (F32.1)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette with multiple overlapping symptoms. The patient presents with severe intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors that align strongly with OCD, especially given the themes of morality, contamination, and harm. The distress and functional impairment are prominent. 

The depressive symptoms are significant and meet criteria for a major depressive episode, though it's important to consider whether they're better explained by the OCD or represent a separate condition. Given their severity and duration, a comorbid MDD seems likely. 

The gender dysphoria is clearly stated, with distress about non-supportive parents and interference with gender expression. The childhood "delusions" sound like possible childhood-onset schizophrenia spectrum, but since they resolved by age 18, it's more of a historical note unless current symptoms suggest otherwise. 

Social anxiety appears chronic and severe, dating back to school years with mutism. The panic attacks are notable but seem tied to OCD distress rather than spontaneous. The asexuality might be related to avoidance of triggering thoughts, so sexual dysfunction could be considered. 

The primary diagnosis should be OCD given the predominance of obsessions and compulsions. MDD and gender dysphoria are clear secondary diagnoses. Social anxiety disorder and panic disorder round out the top five based on the clinical picture.

She denies symptoms consistent with mania or hypomania, including grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, racing thoughts, distractibility, or increased goal-directed activity. The patient acknowledges experiencing an unspecified "extremely traumatic event" but denies re-experiencing it in distressing ways. Assessment ruled out panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, substance use disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders, and generalized anxiety disorder.
diagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, mild (F33)

vignette: Patient is a 24-year-old gender fluid individual with a BA in creative writing and sociology who is currently living with their parents while taking courses part-time and seeking employment. They describe their living situation as "overwhelming" due to parental boundary issues, though they maintain a supportive romantic relationship since 2019. Their psychiatric history includes diagnoses of MDD and GAD at age 15-16, PTSD in 2016 following emotional abuse by high school friends, and ADHD in 2018 (without neuropsychological evaluation). Current medications include Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018), various supplements, and a contraceptive injection. They previously tried multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) but discontinued each after approximately two weeks due to suicidal ideation and, in one case, motor disturbances. The patient consumes alcohol socially (3-5 drinks monthly) and has been vaping marijuana 1-3 times weekly for three months primarily to aid sleep and manage anxiety. The patient's primary symptoms onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs along with perfectionism through rewriting notes until they felt "just right". Currently, they experience significant distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, which would cause severe distress if interrupted. This "not just right" feeling impairs their ability to meet deadlines, complete job applications, and fulfill social obligations. They also engage in checking behaviors when packing (counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items) and experience distressing sexual intrusive thoughts. Additionally, the patient exhibits skin-picking behaviors, spending over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching their neck and jaw during conversations, and tearing at cuticles, with symptoms worsening during periods of anxiety. They've attempted to stop by wearing pants constantly but have been unsuccessful. The patient has a significant history of depression with three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, and 2017) and self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017). They currently experience passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, and concentration problems, though they report 0% chance of self-harm in the next three months. Social anxiety manifests as persistent fear of judgment and rejection, with distressing rumination about social interactions and excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost them friendships. The patient also reported past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months but denied PTSD symptoms. They disclosed a history of binge eating episodes. During the binge, they ate more rapidly than normal and felt disgusted and embarrassed after. After these eating binges, pt fasted for ~3 days. These eating binges occurred <1 time per week, and the patient has not engaged in these behaviors in the past 2 months.
diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (F42.2); Major Depressive Disorder (moderate, recurrent) (F33.1); Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10); Excoriation Disorder (F42.4); Other Specified Eating Disorder: bulimia nervosa (of low frequency and limited duration) (F50.89)
model_thoughts:

Let me start by extracting and organizing the key clinical data systematically. The patient has obsessive-compulsive symptoms including intrusive thoughts, symmetry obsessions, checking rituals, and "not just right" experiences causing significant impairment. There are also body-focused repetitive behaviors with skin picking causing tissue damage. Mood symptoms include persistent depression with past suicide attempts and current passive SI. Anxiety features include social anxiety and generalized worry. There's also mention of binge eating behaviors though currently in remission.

For diagnostic reasoning, the primary issue appears to be obsessive-compulsive disorder given the time-consuming rituals, distress when prevented, and functional impairment. The skin picking meets criteria for excoriation disorder as a separate condition. Major depressive disorder is clearly present with current symptoms and history. Social anxiety disorder is evident from fear of judgment and social avoidance. The binge eating episodes, while not current, warrant inclusion as they occurred regularly.

The challenge is prioritizing these conditions. The OCD symptoms seem most prominent and impairing based on the description, making that the primary diagnosis. The other conditions are significant but appear secondary in clinical presentation.

vignette: The patient is an 18-year-old non-binary college freshman with a complex psychiatric presentation. They report a history of childhood anxiety, perfectionism, and ritualistic self-punishment behaviors starting in the third grade. Currently, their most debilitating symptom is anxiety about "contaminated air" when others cough or sneeze, prompting them to cover their face and hold their breath even when the trigger is far away or on television. They engage in checking and counting behaviors based on the number 3, including checking mirrors while driving, locking/unlocking their car, and tapping their toothbrush. These compulsions are experienced as uncontrollable, with the patient reporting they sometimes modify behaviors (like holding an imaginary door handle in their pocket) when the original compulsion would be disruptive. At approximately age 16, the patient developed anorexia nervosa, restricting their food intake and ultimately requiring intervention from parents and a treatment team. Despite gaining weight under external pressure, the patient continues to restrict eating, has a distinct fear of gaining weight, becoming fat, fasting until dinner, drinking coffee to intentionally upset their stomach. Their BMI currently falls within the normal range. Around the same time their eating disorder developed, the patient experienced depressive symptoms including hopelessness, low motivation, and self-harm behaviors (pulling hair, cutting, punching stomach). They had suicidal ideation during high school, including thoughts of jumping in front of a train and fantasizing about wandering into hallways during a school shooting. Current suicidal thoughts are less frequent and persistent. Current depressive symptoms have been subsyndromal (though not entirely absent) for about 7 months. Specifically, the patient currently denies experiencing depressive symptoms for more than a few hours every couple of weeks but rates their chance of self-harm in the next three months at 50% (suicide attempt chance at 0%). They report minimal alcohol and marijuana use. Notably, the patient expresses resistance to treatment, stating that "getting better means getting fat" and feeling they need to "stay sad for a while longer".
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (F42.2); Anorexia nervosa, restricting type, in partial remission (F50.014); Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in partial remission (F33.41)

vignette: The patient is a 22-year-old female from the Southeastern United States with a history of Depression (2019), Anxiety (2019), and OCD (March 2021). She recently transitioned from working as a childcare specialist to self-employment as a freelancer. Her medical history includes anemia and IBS, for which she takes daily iron supplements. The patient previously attempted treatment with Zoloft (10mg) for OCD symptoms but discontinued due to emotional blunting effects. She reports consuming alcohol 1-2 glasses a few times monthly and using marijuana daily when available, which she finds helpful for intrusive thoughts despite occasionally triggering anxiety. The patient's most distressing symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about sexually harming children, accompanied by physiological responses that she describes as "groinal". These thoughts were particularly distressing during her work as a childcare specialist, where she engaged in compulsive staring at children's genital areas to "prove" she wasn't sexually attracted to them and sometimes avoided changing diapers due to fear of sexual arousal. After experiencing an intrusive dream about sexually harming her brother in January 2021, she experienced physical symptoms (shaking, freezing) when interacting with him and subsequently increased their time together as a form of reassurance. Additionally, the patient reports significant health anxiety focused on getting cancer, HIV, and STIs, leading to excessive symptom research. The patient experiences panic attacks (1-2 times monthly) lasting 15-30 minutes when triggered by intrusive thoughts, with symptoms including shortness of breath, crying, sweating, racing heart, chest pain, and feelings of detachment. She reports seeking reassurance from her mother when these thoughts become overwhelming. The patient also endorses distressing and functionally impairing social anxiety in small groups, leading to significant avoidance; however, she stated that this anxiety is primary due to her unwanted/intrusive thoughts rather than a fear of being judged. She reports experiencing over 50 depressive episodes in the past year, each lasting at least two weeks with symptoms including decreased appetite, sleep disturbance, fatigue, guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death. She described these episodes as challenging to manage, but "not completely debilitating".
diagnosis: OCD, mild, fair insight, with panic (F42.2); Illness Anxiety Disorder (F45.21); Major Depressive Episode, recurrent, moderate (F33.1)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette with multiple overlapping symptoms. Let me start by extracting and organizing the key information systematically. The patient is a 22-year-old female with pre-existing depression, anxiety, and OCD diagnoses. The most prominent symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about harming children with accompanying compulsive behaviors like staring and avoidance. She also has health anxiety, panic attacks, social anxiety, and recurrent depressive episodes.

Okay, looking at the diagnostic reasoning, the intrusive thoughts with compulsive behaviors clearly point toward OCD as the primary issue. The thoughts are ego-dystonic, cause distress, and lead to compulsions—classic OCD presentation. The health anxiety could be part of OCD or a separate illness anxiety disorder, but given the existing OCD diagnosis, it's likely a manifestation of the same condition.

The panic attacks seem triggered by intrusive thoughts rather than spontaneous, so panic disorder might not be the best fit. The social anxiety is explicitly linked to intrusive thoughts too, so it's likely secondary. The depressive episodes are recurrent but not fully debilitating, so persistent depressive disorder might be more appropriate than major depression.

Substance use is present but doesn't appear to be causing the primary symptoms. The marijuana use might even be a form of self-medication for the intrusive thoughts. Rule-outs would include other anxiety and trauma-related disorders, but the core features align most strongly with OCD.
model_diagnosis:
1. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder - ICD-10 F42
2. Illness Anxiety Disorder - ICD-10 F45.21
3. Persistent Depressive Disorder - ICD-10 F34.1
4. Panic Disorder - ICD-10 F41.0
5. Cannabis Use Disorder - ICD-10 F12.20

vignette: Erik is a 10-year-old male who recently completed 4th grade in a gifted math program. He lives with his biological parents and seven-year-old brother, with whom he has "constant" conflict including arguing, screaming, and hitting. Erik has a developmental history of severe temper tantrums prior to age 4, with behavioral challenges emerging in kindergarten and worsening in subsequent grades. His mother reports that her son engages in "constant defiance", experiences rapid mood changes, and demonstrates impulsive behavior, including occasional incidents of pulling knives (though never pointing them at anyone). Daily arguments at home frequently escalate to physical aggression, particularly with his mother and brother. Erik has expressed statements such as "I wish I could go to sleep and never wake up" and reports feeling depressed "randomly" a couple times per month since second or third grade, though he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. Erik's behavioral difficulties have manifested in both home and school environments. In school, he has engaged in speaking out of turn, refusing to follow directions, agitating teachers, and having "screaming matches" with staff. Despite these challenges, Erik maintains high grades across subjects (with math being his most difficult class at a B), has several friends, and is described as a leader in social interactions. He has a Section 504 plan that allows for movement opportunities and frequent breaks when needed. In March 2019, Erik began taking 2mg of Guanfacine (extended release) for attention/concentration deficits, which has helped reduce impulsivity and improve behavioral control, though aggressive and defiant behaviors have continued. His mother reports implementing a point system for rewards and consequences but notes limited effectiveness due to inconsistent expectations between parents. Formal assessment indicates that Erik demonstrates a pattern of emotional dysregulation, defiance, and aggressive behavior, with physical aggression occurring approximately every other day at home. Assessment also confirms prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are present across settings and contribute to emotional dysregulation and academic underperformance relative to ability.
diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Moderate (F91.3); Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Type (F90.2)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the vignette about Erik. He's a 10-year-old male with a history of severe temper tantrums before age 4, and behavioral issues that started in kindergarten and got worse. The key points are constant defiance, rapid mood changes, impulsivity, and physical aggression at home, especially towards his mother and brother. He's pulled knives but never pointed them at anyone.

He also expresses occasional depressive thoughts, like wishing he could sleep and never wake up, and feels depressed randomly a couple times a month since second or third grade. However, he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. So the depressive symptoms seem episodic, not persistent.

At school, he has behavioral issues like speaking out of turn, refusing directions, agitating teachers, and screaming matches. But he maintains high grades, has friends, and is a social leader. There's a Section 504 plan for movement breaks. He's on Guanfacine for attention/concentration deficits, which helps with impulsivity but not the aggression or defiance.

The assessment mentions emotional dysregulation, defiance, aggression, and prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity across settings. So there's a clear pattern of behavioral issues both at home and school, but with some academic and social strengths.

Now, considering DSM-5-TR diagnoses, the primary issues seem to be disruptive behaviors, emotional dysregulation, and attention problems. The most prominent is the aggression, defiance, and temper outbursts. That points towards Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) or maybe Conduct Disorder (CD). Since there's physical aggression but no severe violations of others' rights like stealing or cruelty to animals, ODD seems more fitting. CD would require more severe behaviors.

He also has symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity across settings, which improved with Guanfacine. That strongly suggests ADHD, Combined Presentation, as it's present both at home and school.

The depressive symptoms are occasional, not daily, so it might be a depressive disorder, but not Major Depressive Disorder due to the episodic nature. Could be Other Specified Depressive Disorder or Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD). Given the age of onset before 10, severe temper outbursts, and persistent irritability between outbursts, DMDD fits better than intermittent depressive episodes.

The emotional dysregulation and mood changes are significant, so DMDD might be a consideration, but it requires persistent irritability or anger between outbursts, which is mentioned here. Also, the tantrums started before age 6, which is a criterion for DMDD.

He has friends and good grades, so Autism Spectrum Disorder is less likely since social communication isn't impaired. Anxiety disorders aren't mentioned, so probably not that.

Putting it together, the primary diagnosis should be Oppositional Defiant Disorder because the defiance and aggression are central. Then ADHD due to the attention and impulsivity symptoms. DMDD due to the mood dysregulation and temper outbursts. The depressive symptoms might be part of DMDD or a separate unspecified depressive disorder. Since the aggression is frequent, Intermittent Explosive Disorder could be considered, but ODD already covers the aggression and defiance.

Prioritizing, ODD is most prominent, then ADHD, then DMDD. The depressive episodes are secondary, so Other Specified Depressive Disorder. Maybe Adjustment Disorder, but the issues are chronic, not in response to a recent stressor. So the top five would be ODD, ADHD, DMDD, Other Specified Depressive Disorder, and maybe a rule-out for Conduct Disorder, but since there's no evidence of more severe behaviors, it's lower on the list.
model_diagnosis:
1. Oppositional Defiant Disorder - ICD-10 F91.3
2. Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Presentation - ICD-10 F90.2
3. Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder - ICD-10 F34.81
4. Other Specified Depressive Disorder - ICD-10 F32.89
5. Other Specified Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorder - ICD-10 F91.8

vignette: Dole is a 31-year-old male who arrived for intake with an extensive psychiatric history dating back to age 17, with multiple hospitalizations and diagnoses including Mood Disorder NOS, Bipolar Disorder, Narcissistic Personality Disorder, Schizoaffective Disorder, and Asperger's Syndrome. His symptoms have included paranoid ideation, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusions (such as believing television was sending special messages), obsessive thoughts, compulsive behaviors, and periods of mania and depression. Dole holds a master’s degree in computer science and previously developed cybersecurity systems but resigned in 2019 due to unmanageable anxiety. He currently lives with his parents, who provide significant assistance with daily activities. Throughout his treatment history, Dole has demonstrated paranoid thoughts beginning at age 19, with recurrent episodes of acute psychosis requiring hospitalization. In 2018, he experienced hallucinations of messages on his phone, and in 2019, he reported seeing "the devil" and experiencing auditory hallucinations. He endorses unwanted/intrusive thoughts causing anxiety, which he attempts to neutralize with repetitive behaviors that take 1-3 hours daily. His symptoms include fear of harming himself, violent imagery, concerns about germs, and moral preoccupations. Dole reports deficits in procedural and episodic memory, impairing self-care and accurate recollection of past events. His family history is positive for paternal psychosis, depression with possible bipolar disorder, and a completed suicide. Intake impressions indicate that Dole has experienced (and continues to experience) delusions, hallucinations, disorganized/catatonic behavior, diminished emotional expression, and amotivation within a one-month period. He has exhibited delusions or hallucinations for at least two weeks in the absence of major mood episodes, and his functioning has decreased notably compared to his pre-symptom baseline. Regarding his unwanted/intrusive thoughts, he demonstrates limited insight.
diagnosis: Schizophrenia, Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Episode (F20.9); Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight (F42.2)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with multiple overlapping symptoms spanning psychotic, mood, and obsessive-compulsive domains. The key is to prioritize based on duration, severity, and DSM-5-TR hierarchy.

The intake impressions explicitly note two critical features: psychotic symptoms present for at least two weeks without major mood episodes, and functional decline from baseline. This strongly points to a primary psychotic disorder rather than a mood disorder with psychotic features. Schizophrenia fits best given the chronic course since age 19.

The OCD symptoms appear distinct and time-consuming (1-3 hours daily), meeting criteria for a separate obsessive-compulsive disorder diagnosis. The history of manic and depressive episodes suggests bipolar disorder as a rule-out, but current presentation emphasizes psychotic symptoms without active mood episodes.

Personality pathology is historically noted but less acute than the psychotic and obsessive symptoms. Asperger's syndrome would now fall under autism spectrum disorder in DSM-5-TR. The memory deficits likely relate to the primary psychotic disorder rather than a separate neurocognitive disorder.

The differential must respect diagnostic hierarchy while acknowledging comorbid conditions. Schizophrenia takes precedence due to its severity and chronicity, followed by the clearly documented OCD. The remaining diagnoses should reflect historical patterns and residual symptoms.
model_diagnosis:
1. Schizophrenia - ICD-10 F20.9
2. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder - ICD-10 F42.2
3. Bipolar I Disorder, Most Recent Episode Depressed, With Psychotic Features - ICD-10 F31.5
4. Autism Spectrum Disorder - ICD-10 F84.0
5. Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder - ICD-10 F60.5

vignette: Patient is a 32-year-old Black American male with no prior diagnostic history who presents with a chief complaint of "uncontrollable staring, particularly at breasts/genitals". The patient reports that this behavior began at age 27 (late 2017) and involves involuntary staring at people he does not know well, with particular focus on the genitals/breasts of all genders and ages, including children. He spends approximately six hours per day engaged in or thinking about this behavior, which he cannot control through willpower alone, though he can interrupt it by creating a physical barrier in his line of sight or wearing sunglasses. The patient initially denied but later acknowledged experiencing unwanted sexual thoughts regarding his sexual orientation. This behavior has significantly impaired his functioning, causing him to lose multiple jobs within the past year, avoid family gatherings, limit time in public, and experience relationship strain with his girlfriend of 12 years, with whom he has three children and now stays home while she works. The patient experiences moderate suicidal ideation, including thoughts that he would be better off dead, and reports feeling worthless and guilty, particularly about "not providing for my children and for staring". He describes his mood as "iffy" and notes increased irritability. While the patient endorsed panic attacks on assessment, follow-up questioning revealed these occur specifically when thinking excessively about his staring behaviors or unemployment, rather than occurring spontaneously. He also endorsed criteria for agoraphobia and social anxiety on screening, though these appear directly related to fears of being judged for his staring behavior. The patient acknowledged witnessing a traumatic event he chose not to disclose but denied re-experiencing or avoidance symptoms consistent with PTSD. Medical history includes hypertension treated with Amlodipine (dose unknown), with no psychiatric medication history reported.Throughout the assessment, the patient demonstrated limited insight into his symptoms, was guarded in his responses, and had not disclosed his problems to his long-term partner. While he reported some depressive symptoms, these did not meet sufficient symptoms for major depressive disorder but were nonetheless clinically significant.
diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight, with Panic (F42.2); Other Specified Depressive Disorder (Insufficient Symptoms for MDD) (F32.89)
model_thoughts:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful diagnostic reasoning. The patient presents with several intertwined symptoms that need to be parsed out systematically.

The core issue appears to be the uncontrollable staring behavior with sexual focus, which has persisted for years and consumes significant time daily. This seems to align with obsessive-compulsive features rather than paraphilic or impulse control issues, given the ego-dystonic nature and associated anxiety.

The depressive symptoms are notable but explicitly stated as subthreshold for MDD, so they might be better captured as part of another primary condition or as an adjustment issue. The anxiety symptoms seem secondary to the staring preoccupation rather than independent disorders.

I need to prioritize based on DSM-5 hierarchy and clinical precedence. The obsessive-compulsive pattern affecting multiple life domains should be primary, with secondary conditions accounting for the mood and anxiety components that don't fully meet independent disorder criteria.
model_diagnosis:
1. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder - ICD-10 F42
2. Other Specified Depressive Disorder - ICD-10 F32.8
3. Other Specified Anxiety Disorder - ICD-10 F41.8
4. Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia) - ICD-10 F40.10
5. Agoraphobia - ICD-10 F40.00

vignette: A 32-year-old male with a past medical history of polysubstance use disorder (cocaine, marijuana, and methamphetamine) presents for bizarre behavior brought in by emergency medical services (EMS) after a neighbor called to report that patient was outside her home threatening her with a knife. Per neighbor's report, the patient had been yelling about the FBI and demanding to be let into her home while waving a knife. Patient was yelling at paramedics enroute and attempted to punch a paramedic when being loaded into the ambulance. Upon arrival to the emergency room, patient was agitated, requiring emergency intermuscular injection of medications to deescalate. Patient told doctors in the emergency room that he felt unsafe and needed them to watch his knives for him. He felt like the government was going to come get him and use the weapons in his home against him. He recalls going to the neighbor's home in an attempt to have her hide his knives for him. A few hours later, the psychiatry team came to evaluate the patient, at which point the patient appeared drowsy and asked to be left alone due to feeling tired. He refused to provide urine sample but allowed a blood draw. His blood work returned with elevated white blood count (WBC) at 18 x10e3/uL. He denied having any prior psychiatric diagnoses but admitted that he has been using methamphetamine recently. He recalls he had been admitted to an inpatient psychiatry service before, around 1 year prior after using meth, where he stayed for 3 days and was discharged on Seroquel, which patient denied currently taking. He does not recall his diagnosis from that admission. Patient agreed to receive further care at a psychiatric facility and was voluntarily transferred to an inpatient psychiatry unit. Patient was started again on Seroquel but refused to take it during admission. He was seen napping during the day and reported some stomach cramping to the treatment team. By day 3 of admission, patient reported feeling well and signed himself out of the hospital.
diagnosis_icd: Other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance-induced psychotic disorder with delusions (F19.150)
reasoning: Patient only has known history of 1 prior episode of psychosis, which appeared to be in the setting of substance use (meth). Patient this time also admitted to using meth recently. While urine sample was not obtained, an elevated WBC can be indicative of methamphetamine use in the absence of infection. Additionally, fatigue and gastrointestinal upset are common symptoms of stimulant withdrawal. Resolution of symptoms in a short course of only 3 days and without medication is another evidence for substance-induced psychosis rather than a primary psychotic disorder. However, with such limited history, an underlying primary psychotic disorder cannot be fully ruled out and thus antipsychotic treatment may still be indicated.

vignette: A 16-year-old male in the 9th grade with no known past psychiatric history presented as a walk-in admission to the county psychiatric hospital with his mother. When patient was interviewed directly, he appeared constricted and dysphoric, with hair covering his eyes. He spoke softly. He reported that he has been feeling angry because he has been thinking more about how his biological father used to abuse his mom, even though his biological father no longer is in their life. He reports that he has been experiencing poor memory, poor concentration, feeling anxious and ruminating frequently. He also admits to having thoughts of death several months ago and does have access to guns although he has never attempted to kill himself. He does report that he intentionally cut his wrist a few months ago to cope with his feelings but denied having suicidal intent. He also endorses poor sleep and low mood. He admits that he is a long-time bars user (referring to Xanax) but does not know the dosage and is evasive when asked about his frequency and most recent use. He also reports that he smokes marijuana but again does not provide details regarding his use. He states that more recently, he started using marijuana specifically to help with new-onset paranoia. He describes his mind playing tricks on him, morphing objects into faces leading to feeling scared. Lab work collected at the hospital did not show abnormalities other than a positive urine cannabinoid screen. First, the psychotic symptoms stand out: paranoia about neighbors spying/harming him, perceptual disturbances (objects morphing into faces), and these emerged alongside depressive symptoms. The depressive symptoms are significant too: dysphoric mood, irritability, wall-punching, past self-harm without suicidal intent, poor sleep, and concentration issues. Substance use complicates the picture - regular Xanax and marijuana use, with marijuana possibly used to self-medicate paranoia. The positive cannabinoid screen confirms recent use. However, the rapid improvement on fluoxetine and aripiprazole suggests the psychotic and depressive symptoms were medication-responsive.

Considering differentials: psychotic disorder due to another medical condition seems less likely given normal labs. Brief psychotic disorder is possible but the duration isn't specified. She became concerned for the potential of chemical irritation on his skin. When patient was addressed directly, patient reports that he needs everything to be clean. He expresses an intense fear that his belongings and space are contaminated with germs if he does not clean then regularly. He alludes to his view of the outside as “dirty” and that his room is “clean.” He feels the intense urge to have anything that enters his room to be decontaminated otherwise his whole room will become contaminated. He describes an intense feeling of anxiety if he cannot clean things before they enter his room. He states that he spends a lot of time washing his hands because if he misses a spot or brushes his hand against the side of the sink, he needs to start over to ensure that they are fully clean. He also denies feeling depressed prior to the fight. He states that his friends and loved ones “always” leave him and that he was hurt because he thought his girlfriend was different. When asked about outpatient care, he expressed a mistrust for mental health providers, stating that most of them “just don’t get it” and that he is still working on finding a therapist who understands him. He says that the last clinic assigned him a female provider even though he requested a male provider. He admits that they stated they didn’t have any male providers available at the time, but still feels that they betrayed him by making him false promises. He endorses feeling like he isn’t worth other people’s time and feeling depressed often, especially when relationships or friendships don’t work out. He denies recent insomnia, appetite changes, concentration or memory issues, and anhedonia. He is seen to have multiple healed lacerations on bilateral forearms, which he states are scars from cutting. He asks the provider if they think he may have bipolar disorder or autism because he feels like he gets “mood swings” and has difficulty in keeping friends. He also demonstrates a fear of abandonment (threat of a breakup is what triggered this episode) and feeling that people “always leave” him. This suicide attempt is not secondary to major depressive disorder (MDD) as he does not have the criteria for MDD of >2 weeks of low/depressed mood or anhedonia.

When asked her reason for staying, she stated that she just “did not feel ready” to return home yet because being around her mother-in-law stressed her out.
